On 12/7/10 8:01 AM, tuxzone wrote:
> Hello,
>
> What is the best place to do Heritrix feature requests?

This is a good place, especially if you want wider discussion. Or you 
can go directly to the project JIRA issue tracker, where anyone can 
register, submit issues, and comment:

https://webarchive.jira.com/browse/HER

> If it is this list, I have two:
>
> 1. A configuration option whether or not Heritrix should try to
> discover new URLs in 404-pages. As a default, I think it should not
> (now it does). This feature will help preventing crawler traps.

I've made an issue for this:

https://webarchive.jira.com/browse/HER-1848

The existing ExtractorHTML setting 'ignoreUnexpectedHTML' may be of some 
help in such cases -- it suppresses HTML link-extraction for certain 
URLs whose format strongly suggests they should have been some other 
media type, as is the case for some 'soft 404' situations -- but I agree 
we should offer a more general discovery-suppression for 404 errors.

Note that a possible workaround in the meantime is to add a 
shouldProcess DecideRule to relevant extractors that answers 'REJECT' 
for 404s (and possibly other error codes). The FetchStatusDecideRule or 
ScriptedDecideRule could be used for this purpose.

> 2. Support for the canonical link element (see
> http://googlewebmastercentral.blogspot.com/2009/02/specify-your-canonical.html).
> This should be configurable. When support is enabled (default should
> be 'disabled') only the canonical pages should be written. As an
> extra option it should be configurable whether / how far non
> canonical pages (ie. pages that have a non empty canonical link
> element) should be followed for detecting new URLs. Again, this
> feature will help preventing crawler traps (although I think the
> element isnï¿½t widely applied yet) and might support better
> accessibility of the content of web archives).

I've made an issue for this as well:

https://webarchive.jira.com/browse/HER-1849

In practice, I don't know whether this link-relation will be a strong 
guarantee that the 'canonical' URI is the better one to store, or that 
the non-canonical URIs should be discarded. For example, even in 
Google's example of a 'good example' at Wikia, discarding the 
non-canonical fetch would lose information about terms considered 
synonyms, and possibly break inlinks to archive URLs that would have 
worked for analogous URLs on the original site. So this might be a 
valuable signal, but not in exactly the manner intended by its 
search-index originators.

- Gordon @ IA
